oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee State Historical Marker 3A 32, Demonbreun’s Cave, Nashville, Tennessee, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A Tennessee Historical Commission marker commemorating Demonbreun’s Cave located on the Cumberland River. It reads: “Jacques-Timothe De Montbrun, French Canadian fur trader and later lieutenant governor of the Illinois Country, visited this area as early as 1769. On at least one occasion he took refuge in the cave 0.9 mile E. when attacked by Indians. He settled in Nashville in 1790, living there until his death in 1826.” Timothy Demonbreun's Cave historical marker was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on February 2nd, 1980. Forms part of the Bill Goodman Photographic Slides Collection. 1 35 mm negative.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Demonbreun family
